Award.AwardTitle: NeuroNex Innovation Award: Southwest Magnetogenetics Project (SoMa)
Award.AbstractNarration:
To better understand how the brain functions, scientists are in search of new methods to activate specific neurons in laboratory animals without restricting their behaviors. This research effort will create technologies that rely on magnetic fields to stimulate specific, genetically modified neurons. A major advantage of this "magnetogenetic" technology is fact that magnetic fields easily penetrate bone, skin and tissue making it easier for scientists to probe the role of specific cells deep within the body without using any implanted devices that could otherwise interfere with normal animal behavior or cause damage to the target tissue. Better understanding of how the brain works in laboratory animals will help reveal fundamental principles of computation in the brain that may apply across animal species to include humans. This deeper understanding of the brain is key for developing better diagnosis and treatments for neural disorders and to improve artificial systems like neural networks designed to operate like the human brain.

This work will focus on understanding how biogenic magnetic nanoparticles tethered to temperature sensitive ion channels render specific cells sensitive to magnetic fields. The major goals of this effort will be the development of a comprehensive theory for the mechanism of action for these magnetogenetic channels, and the creation of a set of transgenic fly lines that display robust behavioral responses to magnetic fields. These magnetogenetic fly lines will be compatible with Gal4/UAS system such that magnetogenetic channels can be easily targeted to specific cells. The outcome of this work will be both a fundamental understanding of magnetogenetic mechanisms and a set of transgenic fly strains that will empower researchers to probe neural circuits in this common model organism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to modulate the activity of specific neuron populations is essential for studying and treating many neurological disorders, including epilepsy, Parkinsons, depression and chronic pain. Currently, the methods used to modulate neural activity involve drug therapies, which have a slow kinetics, electric stimulation, which requires invasive procedures, or optogenetics, which has a limited spatial range and penetration depth. 

Our research objective is to develop new tools to remotely stimulate neurons using magnetic fields. Our long-term vision is that magnetogenetic neuromodulation will allow scientists to control activity in specific cells types throughout the entire brain using no probes, tethers, or behavioral restriction. Furthermore, we envision that this modulation will turn on and off at the speed of a single action potential (100 Hz). Thanks to this award, we have been able to develop a new method to stimulate a defined population of neurons in vivo using a magnetic field, yielding sub-second behavioral responses. 

The project started with theoretical and experimental work aimed at understanding the biophysical mechanisms and optimal stimulation conditions of an engineered protein called Magneto 2.0, previously developed by the Guler lab. This new protein consists of the cell membrane channel TRPV4 associated to the nanoparticle ferritin, both genetically encoded. Our work, published in the Biophysical Journal (Duret et al. 2019), proposed that the channel’s temperature sensitivity could be the basis of the reported magnetic response. Based on this, we investigated  i) proteins that respond better to fast temperature changes ii) nanoparticles that produce more energy than ferritin. 

Using optimized thermo receptors and synthetic magnetite nanoparticles, we were able to modulate the activity of neurons in the brain of fruit flies and effectively trigger measurable behavioral effect in less than 1 second of stimulation. This is ~10 times faster than previously published approaches that used magnetic fields as a stimulus. 

In order to transition this technology to warm blooded organisms, we have explored the temperature sensitivity of other thermoreceptors and have identified 2 promissing candidates. Our initial results using these proteins in combination with both artificial and genetically coded nanoparticle have shown rapid and reproducible activation in vitro.
